docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of Yonkers workers are at the crux of a continuing debate in the city about a “living wage” proposal that would make Yonkers the first Westchester municipality to increase the hourly wage above the state minimum.

headline.main: Proposal Seeks a Break for Low-Wage Workers

docs.lead_paragraph: On Long Island, a case against 10 Filipino nurses is a startling anomaly in what has been a remarkably successful migration of people seeking to work in a single occupation.

headline.sub: Recruited, Soured by Labor Dispute, 10 Await Trial  Accused of Walking Off,  Leaving Patients Behind;

docs.lead_paragraph: In an interview with The Times about health policy on Wednesday, former Senator John Edwards said that his proposal to require all legal United States residents to have health insurance did not include a hardship exemption. Such an exemption, which exists in Massachusetts, the only state to mandate insurance coverage so far, would allow the granting of waivers to those who cannot afford premiums, even after they are heavily subsidized by the government.

headline.main: Edwards Aide Clarifies Health Care Stance

docs.abstract: A candidate's Web site says one thing, while the candidate says another
docs.snippet: A candidate's Web site says one thing, while the candidate says another

docs.lead_paragraph: Viewers tuned in to Thursday night's debate between the leading Republican candidates may have been expecting a brutal, no-holds-barred attack show like the Democrats put on Monday night. Instead, though, the G.O.P. hopefuls kept their remarks to one another mostly friendly.

headline.main: The Early Word: G.O.P. Keep It Civil

docs.abstract: The Republican presidential candidates kept their discourse focused on the economy, not personal attacks, at Thursday night's debate in Boca Raton, Fla.
docs.snippet: The Republican presidential candidates kept their discourse focused on the economy, not personal attacks, at Thursday night's debate in Boca Raton, Fla.
